blocks.text: Example 30.—To find the time to empty a tank, of area $A$ sq. ft., through an orifice of area $a$ sq. ft., the coefficient of discharge being $C_{d}$.
If the height of the water above the orifice at any time is $h$, the velocity of discharge w is given by

blocks.description: This equation expresses the velocity of water discharge through an orifice based on the height of the water above the orifice.

blocks.text: The quantity escaping in time $dt$ is $A \cdot w \cdot dt = A \cdot C_{d} \sqrt{2gh} \cdot dt$.
This will result in a lowering of the level in the tank by an amount $dh$, so that the volume $V = A_{t}h$ in time $dt$ is given by $V = A_{t}(h - dh)$.
Here we have a single differential equation to solve, separating the variables and integrating:

blocks.description: A differential equation relating the change in height of water to time.

blocks.text: Solving this gives the final height $h$ in terms of the initial height.
If $h_{0}$ is the height, then the time to completely empty the tank is:

blocks.description: This equation provides the total time to empty the tank based on initial height, areas, and discharge coefficient.

blocks.text: Example 31.—To gauge the flow of water by measurements with a triangular notch.
Let the height at the notch be $H$, and consider a small element of width $b$, thickness $h$, and depth $H - h$, where $\theta = \angle$ the notch of the notch.

blocks.caption: Fig. 126.—Triangular Notch
blocks.description: A diagram of a triangular notch used for measuring water flow.
